bibl.title: Despatch from Alexander G. Clark to William F. Wharton, January 10, 1891
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No 9 Consulate General Series, United States Legation Monrovia, Liberia January 10, 1891, Mr Alexander Clark to the Department of State
No 9 Consulate General Series:, United States Legation Monrovia Liberia January 10, 1891.
To the Honorable William F. Wharton Assistant Secretary of State Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor to respectfully acknowledge the receipt of your circulars of November 3rd and 8th 1890 marked [(S2) 11,,3:90-500)(Sd 11,,11:-90-1000) agricultural Department] with there accompanying inclosures viz 1. Regulation for inspecting cattle 2. ,, ,, ,, Salt meets: also circular marked (SD 11,, 8-90-1000 viz. Sheet and Roadways; In reply I am to say that there are no cattle or salt meets exported from Monrovia or any port of the Republic of Liberia [as per circulars marked (SD 11,,3,,90-500)]

or (SD- 11-90-1000; Indeed live stock of all kind are of a very infoerior kind; the cows weight from 455 hundred giving from a print to print and one half of milks sheep, goats are small weighing from 20 to 50 pounds - hogs weight from one pound to 125 chicken are small no horses in the country or a least in Monrovia;

Circular marked (SD 11, 8,'' 90-1000) Streets and roadways &c; Monrovia Liberia though the Cappital of the Republic with a population variously estimated from 3000 to 5000 have not a street or alley pavid; The Streets and alleys are merely covered with grass and weeds intermingle with beautiful wild flowers the side walks are in places cleared by cutting out the grass, the city of Monrovia is situated at an altitude of 300 to 400 feet above the level of the sea. on a rock covering the sight on which the only rest

There are no waggons wheel barrows; go east on wheel vehicle of any kind used in the city or country the houses are brick and fram in the city proper mostly two story high enclosed by stone fences the two Snburban towns, viz Kroo, townand vie town are a part of the corporate limits of Monrovia The people of these two precincts are Natives- viz Kroo-men and vie-men; the Post office is in Kroo town. which to reach it make a nice letter walk of 2 1/2 miles from the center of the city proper. The Kroo and Vie houses are made of thatches with dirt floors and my opinion is that they are healthier than the brick home. The legation building are the finest and best built house in the city but like all the brick houses it is damp and unhealthy and

and there are no exceptions to the houses being damp in the rainy season which commences in October and holdes till the first of April. I am satisfied that for central location looks and convience no better house could be secured and as the lease of it by Mr John H Smyth has expired some two years ago and on renewed of said lease I have re-leased it upon the same terms for two years from Jany just (1) 1891- which I hope will eet your approval &c I have the honor to be your obedient servant
